Dark Souls II is a game that evokes a lot of mixed feelings in me. DS2 is a game that does a lot of experimenting and big risks that ultimately put the experience somewhere between okay and downright awful. I've seen a lot of comments that the hate is overblown and it is actually a very good and maybe even the best DS game. While I agree the hate was overblown I can't help but think that we're swinging too far the other way with how much it's being praised. Since I am going to be pretty critical, let's start with the things I like.

The Good:

DS2 has a very addictive gameplay loop, despite the flaws I'll talk about later on in the review. The progression of weapons, armor, and skills feels really good and the pacing of getting stronger is genuinely really fun. This might be the primary reason why I'm able to mostly look past it's issues. Likewise, DS2's weapon and armor design is pretty good, I always looked forward to trying out new weapons and armor. Though I've only played through it once, it's easy to see that the flexibility and variety of builds far outstrips the original as well.

What DS2 does right, it does really well. NPCs are also a major highlight of the game for me. DS1's NPCS, while charming, always felt more mysterious and distant. DS2's NPCs feel more like real, living people and not like phantoms, which lends to DS2's overall atmosphere of a world that is beginning to die as opposed to DS1's atmosphere of a world that's been long dead. Majula in particular really enhances this, feeling like a growing community with each new NPC you discover. If you talk to certain NPCs enough, they'll give you gifts which is a nice touch. The NPCs you talk to have backgrounds, goals, and fears. While you could say that DS1's NPCs have these things, they're just more fleshed out in DS2. It just makes the hub and world feel a little more alive and connected.

The Bad:

Okay, now for the bad, which there is a lot of. The biggest, most glaring issue that trumps anything else is the design philosophy when it comes to making difficult encounters, which is: throw massive amounts of enemies and hazards at the player. DS2 is infamous for its ganks and to be completely honest, that is terrible game design. When comparing it to DS1, which had intentional and clever placement of enemies that were at a manageable number, DS2 will have giant groups of enemies rush you from across the map. Additionally, they will rarely break aggro and will chase you down if you try to run past, while attempting a boss for example. This forces you to fight these hordes of enemies every single time you're trying to beat a boss, which can get miserable quickly. Add onto the fact for some of the hardest bosses, like those in the DLCs, have brutal boss runs with not only hordes of enemies but also environmental hazards or enemies shooting magic at you from afar. It's not clever, it's not fun, it's just creating difficulty through volume as opposed to unique, quality move sets.

The hit boxes in this game are criminal. Everyone knows about the adaptability skill and how infuriatingly crucial it is to level it to reach a point that was just default in DS1 but beyond that, the hit boxes for enemies is just unfair. Enemies will be able to snatch you when you're multiple feet away, outside of their attack animations. Or they'll be able to damage you when their animations indicate they missed. I don't know if this was a design choice or an oversight but it's atrocious and very unfair. Another very poor gameplay decision was the constant loss of health for every death that you can only reverse with human effigies, a finite resource in the game. In a game series about constantly dying over and over, punishing the player for dying is abysmal design. It just sucks.

Finally, one of the biggest disappointments for me was the art design and atmosphere. Many people talk about how DS2 has the best atmosphere of the trilogy and that's just not true. DS1's atmosphere of darkness, mystery, and despair has been replaced in DS2 with an atmosphere that frankly feels cheaper in all respects. While some areas in DS2 have a good atmosphere and feel reminiscent of DS1 (Drangleic Castle, Majula) many others feel out of place and honestly like a theme park. Iron Keep and Huntsman's Copse make me feel like I'm playing WoW and that is the antithesis of the central visual themes of the dark souls series. This goes down to even how the undead look. In DS1, the undead's skin was stretched, dehydrated, withered. The undead in DS2 look like a stereotypical frankenstein costume, it's embarrassing. The boss designs, for the most part, do not help this. Many of the bosses in DS2 are generic, fantasy stereotypes as opposed to the unique twists on classic fantasy tropes that FromSoft is known for. Generic skeleton bosses, knight bosses, or demon bosses (some of which are very important to the story) make me feel like I'm playing a low quality MMO. Not to mention the reuse of bosses from DS1, there are a number of rehashes from DS1 that are just worst in every way (Ornstein, Bell Gargoyles). It's just lazy and uninspired. There are, of course, good boss designs but they are by far the exceptions and not the rule.

Overall, DS2 is a very flawed entry in FromSoft's catalogue and honestly if I hadn't played it with my friends, I don't know that I would have even finished the base game. My recommendation is that if you're souls crackhead like me and you see it on sale, pick it up and give it a try. It's far from the horrible game people made it out to be on launch but it's certainly not the brilliant, misunderstood underdog of the series that people today keep claiming it is.
Different from the other souls games, but for being seemingly the most hated souls game, it's still better than 90% of games out there.

Dark Souls II: At the End of Ash, There Is Still Light

I still remember the first time I arrived at Majula.
That seaside ruin, swept by a damp wind, had almost nothing‚Äî
a bonfire, a windmill, a silent woman.
The sunlight was pale, the air was salty, and the music felt like a memory.
Back then, I didn‚Äôt yet understand that Dark Souls II wasn‚Äôt a game to ‚Äúbeat.‚Äù
It was a world meant to be felt‚Äîa world that had already fallen apart, but where people still refused to vanish.

This game never hurries to tell you anything.
It doesn‚Äôt throw its story into your face like most games do.
It simply stands there, silent, waiting to see if you can find meaning within the ruins.
Like those moments in life when you walk into an empty place‚Äîno one explains it to you, but you know it once mattered.

I

The map of Dark Souls II isn‚Äôt perfect.
Its world isn‚Äôt a miracle of interlocking design, but a crumbling labyrinth.
And yet, I love this imperfection.
It feels like reality itself: paths split, meanings blur, landscapes collapse into one another without logic.
You keep walking‚Äîthrough poison fogs, into castles, down into caverns‚Äîand everywhere there‚Äôs that mute sense of history.
The world feels like the corpse of the past, and we are wandering inside its bones.

I died in the same place over and over, until frustration turned into quiet concentration.
With every death, I memorized a stone‚Äôs edge, an enemy‚Äôs rhythm, a hidden shortcut.
The game, in punishing you, is also teaching you.
It‚Äôs teaching you what it means to endure‚Äîto find worth inside repetition.
Each time you rise from the ashes, you‚Äôre not just playing; you‚Äôre existing.

II

And the story? It barely speaks.
The NPCs mumble fragments, as if they‚Äôve forgotten who they once were.
Yet that silence makes everything more human.
I began to imagine their pasts, to stitch meaning from scraps.
Each item description reads like a torn letter; each boss feels like a fallen king, a knight, or a mother whose memory curdled into wrath.

Dark Souls II never tells you who is good or evil.
It only shows how time erodes will.
You witness kingdoms decaying, ideals dissolving, the flame itself fading‚Äî
and still, you keep walking.
There‚Äôs no reason, no reward, only a journey you cannot stop taking.

III

I‚Äôve always loved its light‚Äînot sunlight, but the trembling light of a torch.
When you walk into a cavern and raise that flickering flame,
the walls glisten with moisture, and the air itself feels rotten.
It‚Äôs terrifying, yet strangely peaceful.
The beauty of Dark Souls is not the kind that pleases the eyes;
it‚Äôs the beauty of order born from ruin.

A broken cathedral, a rusted suit of armor, a banner waving in a dead wind‚Äî
these things remind you the world isn‚Äôt dead,
it‚Äôs merely been forgotten.

IV

I think about the combat‚Äîit‚Äôs cruel, but honest.
It destroys arrogance, dismantles impatience.
It doesn‚Äôt care how skilled you are; it only demands sincerity.
When I finally defeated a boss, I didn‚Äôt feel triumph.
I felt something quieter‚Äîa breath after exhaustion.

You look at the fallen creature,
the message ‚ÄúSoul Acquired‚Äù appears,
and you wonder: What did I actually win?

Perhaps nothing. Perhaps only survival.
And maybe that‚Äôs enough.
Because life, too, rarely rewards effort with applause.
It simply asks us to keep breathing through the pain.

V

When the final door opened and the fire awaited, I didn‚Äôt feel joy.
I felt hollow‚Äîlike I had witnessed the end of a world.
Yet within that hollowness, I began to understand what ‚Äúsoul‚Äù really means.

Dark Souls never glorifies strength; it glorifies the will to keep living beneath collapse.
It‚Äôs a tragic kind of romance‚Äî
the fire will die,
and still we choose to light it.

So when I lifted my head from the screen
and saw the first pale light of dawn outside my window,
I realized something simple:

Life itself is a long, dark soul.
You stumble through fog, awaken by the bonfire,
unsure of the goal‚Äîonly knowing you must keep walking.

And when morning finally comes,
and you look back upon the ruins, you‚Äôll understand‚Äî
you never conquered the darkness.
You merely learned how to walk within it.

Look. I actually do not recommend this game at all to pretty much anyone. But there is no "ehhhhhh" middle ground option and a flat negative *only just* scans as unfair to me. I really had to think about it though because my god what a mess... 

The first-half of this re-release scans to me as self-parody - a comical overcompensation for those who felt base DS2 was too empty, too uncanny, or god forbid too easy. I actually think everything up to Drangleic Castle is MUCH MUCH WORSE in this version. It is borderline unenjoyable. 

If you have ever had someone tell you "enemy placement is much better in Scholar", they are lying to you. Horribly. Every moment of infamy that earns DS2 its polarising reputation comes from Scholar's "revisions". The Iron Keep was not that bad in base game, and it's entirely because of how they tweaked the AI. It's a quadrupling down on a tedious design paradigm - there are only so many times "luring it out required ahead" can be read without your eyes rolling.

So, why a thumbs up? Moddability, mostly - DS2 Lighting Engine has this game looking far better than it has any right to, and while there's only so far you can go to work around deeply inconsistent art direction, it works around one of the biggest issues with the original experience which was that it was hideous 90% of the time. I also think the revisions to the late game are generally nicer - the Dragon Shrine and the castle are the two main examples in my mind. 

Other notable alterations... getting the ember for infusions early is a total nothingburger of a change to me, and removes any excitement in looking for it as well as facilitating the noob trap of early-game infusing just because you can, so I don't care for it. Changing the Bastille Key to be attainable without much effort also seems pointless. Just... deeply weird changes all round. Not the kind of revisions that this game so deeply needed.

As for the DLCs being thrown in... well at least one of them is good! The Sunken King DLC is by far my favourite passage of this game, actually enjoyable to explore and two out of the three bosses are genuinely great. Iron King was an immediate return to the awfulness of Scholar design ideology, just full of terrible ideas and only Fume Knight to save it. Not worth the slog. Eleum Loyce is SO CLOSE to being up there as the best area - great exploration, decent bosses in the main section - and they just couldn't help themselves and HAD to throw the Frigid Outskirts in there, which might well be the worst area in a game full of bad ones. God awful stuff.

So. If you've had someone say "DS2 is bad but the DLCs are good"... no! No they're not. Not good enough to be worth all that. But if you are like me, and you just have to know... well. I'd probably still recommend playing base game with the season pass. But if you want to mod the game then this is the release you go for. Just pretend the first five to ten hours didn't happen. Trust that if you think you're the kind of person who can do that, you will find that self-belief tested. It really is as bad as everyone says. 

As before - I enjoy that this is the first souls-like to streamline set building in the post-game, infinite titanite vendors are a good idea and actually getting to engage with the mechanical complexity on offer once the humiliation ritual of the campaign is over provides a surprisingly large amount of redemption. If you beat all the DLC and get the King's Blessing, Bonfire Ascetic-ing the areas you want to see in NG+ while wearing the stuff that stops you from hollowing gives you a glimpse of the few good ideas in here working at their best. 

Somewhere in the collective consciousness exists a "good" version of DS2. Neither one of them actually are. Playing both of these versions to find out felt like putting my hand on a stove for 100 hours. But you really do have to see for yourself, I suppose.

[h1]Dark Souls II is one of the most controversial games in the series.[/h1] 
It is often called the black sheep because of its unusual mechanics and design choices. Yet, despite its reputation, it has amassed a devoted fanbase. Its atmosphere and lore are unmatched, offering a distinct sense of melancholy and mystery. While many players describe their experience with the game as a love-hate relationship, I‚Äôve seen firsthand how it can surprise newcomers. Contrary to common advice that DS2 isn't beginner-friendly, my girlfriend recently started playing and found it approachable and genuinely satisfying despite just having played and finished DS3 as her first ever Souls game.



[h1]The advantages:[/h1] 

It has a unique atmosphere and world design. It makes you feel sad and gives you the urge to explore, which is probably the most beautiful of any Souls game.

DLC expansions: The Crown of the Ivory King is especially popular. People like it because it is well-made, challenging, and offers exciting experiences.

There are many different builds and customization options: There's a lot of flexibility in the playstyles, from powerstancing to magic hybrids.

Rewarding progression loop: It's fun and keeps you playing.

Majula: This is such an iconic hub that it deserves its own mention.



[h1]Cons:[/h1] 

Level design and enemy placement: too many gank squads and frustrating layouts.

The game's mechanics are clunky. Healing feels sluggish, and the hitboxes are inconsistent, which makes combat less precise until you get ADP up.

Death penalty system: losing max health each time you die can be discouraging. It feels punishing, but it does make you want to play with other people to regain humanity items, which I consider a plus.

Boss quality: there are twice as many bosses as in other games. Some are easy or not too difficult, but many are much more unique than the other entries. They have cool extra features that change how the environment works, which makes the battles more interesting. Definitely better than Dark Souls I, but about equal to DS3 (mostly because DS3 is so smooth when it comes to gameplay).

[h1]Recommendation:[/h1]
Dark Souls II is best for players who are already familiar with the series and want to experience its unique take on the formula. Veterans may notice its flaws, but newcomers can still enjoy it, especially if they like the atmosphere and unusual elements.

It's also much more open and expansive than the other games in the series, originally intended as an open‚Äëworld title like Elden Ring is today. Because of changes in development and leadership, that vision was scaled back, but you can still see the traces of it  making DS2 feel bigger and different in scope compared to its predecessors.

At this point, I've played most Fromsoft games, and I feel like I can give a meaningful review. Maybe. Take it with a grain of salt: DS1, 2, 3, Bloodborne, and Elden Ring (minus the DLC).

This might be long, though I generally write as stream of consciousness. Forgive my rambling.

These games aren't about difficulty. Sure, it enhances the game, but if your sole reason for playing this game is the PVP or the bosses, fine, I guess? But really they're more philosophical if anything. Eat some hot sauce if that's your thing. Or touch grass. Anyways.

DS2 iterates on its predecessor in that it elaborates what it means to be human, and the purpose of existence itself. In my opinion. [Spoiler] The first sin is Gwyn linking the fire because he went against the nature of things, which are cyclical. He broke recursion of light to dark and prolonged fire, which is to say civilization. [/spoiler]

In a sense, Dark Souls and Fromsoft games in general are concerned with religion, myth, and are our modern day version of the Illiad, or Odyssey, etc. That much is clear to me. But that does it a disservice, in a sense this is a form of art. The beauty of Dark Souls is it doesn't hold your hands, but it's fair. You have the choice to interact with the NPCs, to learn of the world. Or maybe you won't. You can do a strength build - a mage build, whatever. There are ways to make the game easier or harder based on that playstyle, and typically, it's the barrier to entry that makes it difficult.

Anyways, gameplay, because obligatory. When you understand the core basic mechanics of the genre, it becomes a lot easier - allocate stats, put on armour, upgrade armour, upgrade weapon, scale with highest stats. The mechanic people don't like, hollowing, can be avoided by just by putting more health to offset that gap. The game sells plenty of anti-hollowing stuff later, and it's really pushing a feeling on you. If there's a boss you're having trouble with, explore elsewhere. There is subtle telegraphing, and more often than not, if you're bashing your head against a wall, try a different angle. I think you can re-spec your character, or can learn to, 5 times? That's another thing, so you're encouraged to experiment. You can equip multiple spells to increase usage, and you can use consumables to use more spells as well - spell-casting is a lot more fun in this game than in a lot of others.

One of the spots I had most trouble with my play-through was because I did not explore the windmill and kept brute forcing the auto-health boss. I explored, discovered how to stop the auto-heal, and it was much easier. I'm keeping it vague because spoilers, but if you've played you know what I mean. That is precisely the feeling it's going for - hopelessness, and then triumph when stepping back. It tells its story through setting, environment, and aesthetics.

If this is your first game, come back once you've played a different entry to dip your toes in so to speak. Or dive in, either way, I can see on both sides why people find this divisive- it really boils down to how you interact with media, and therefore I cannot recommend this to most people, not out of an elitist mentality, but simply because Dark Souls doesn't explain itself and is sort of an anti-game, in the sense that most work with and for the player, where Dark Souls is actively challenging you perspective-wise.

Perhaps I missed the point. I can accept that. In any case, I finished the base game as of this review, but I definitely plan on trying the DLC at some point. ([strike] I did not do the ending because you restart from the beginning if you do that, and I want to do the ending once I've beaten the DLC. That's also a thing [/strike]) If you finish the game, you can choose whether to restart. Regardless, if you like Dark Souls 1 & 3, you might like Dark Souls 2, though maybe not.

Hard to recommend to newcomers of FromSoft or the Souls genre as most of the game's highlights are near end-game/at post-game, but it is a good time if you can stick it out.

The bad:

The legendary atmosphere the first game is just missing.

Much weaker environmental storytelling

Vendrick and the other major players aren't as clearly highlighted as Gwyn & his lords.

The combat feels less meaty, more flaily, than the first game.

There are tons of 'dead' level ups that you need to do in order to get utility points.

More throwaway bosses than in the previous title.

There are some difficulty spikes-here-and-there, but before the post-game, this entry is significantly significantly significantly easier than its predecessor.

The good:

The checkpoints are, for the most part, not hidden and are much more plentiful.

Still some issues figuring out what to do to advance, but not nearly as bad as its predecessor.

Most areas between the boss and the next checkpoint are rather short and easy.

Multi-boss fights have more openings to interact with opponents

Titanite slabs are much more abundant.

The post-game content is better than pretty much anything seen in DS1 (save the first half of the Artorias DLC in DS1).

Bosses' hitboxes and animations are much better aligned here than the previous title.

There is some BS, but nothing here is as terrible as Lost Izalith or the Tomb of Giants.

After beating the game you'll want to beat the ENTIRE game again, rather than in DS1 where you want to repeatedly just finish Anor Londo then restart.

Still beautiful, still Dark Souls.

Another small problem is that the player character doesn't seem to be entirely ambidextrous (but is still ambidextrous, in DS1 and 3, holding an axe in your left hand will block with the axe, and holding a shield in your right hand will start attacking with the shield, which is completely dumb). For some enemy types (I only tested two, with slash damage) the left hand seems to deal less damage than the right hand. I'm sure he was also the genius behind the double clicking idea as well, which has to be enabled and disabled each time you launch the game, because they refused to fix this bug, if you don't want input delay. Balancing is actually very good (except for Iron Keep, which is a bit overkill to be honest), some buffs are are a little bit overpowered, there are still ways to one shot bosses, but it's still mostly balanced, especially PvP (or maybe I just didn't get enough minmax builds). And yes, Shrine of Amana was as great as you can imagine.
Bonfire ascetics make replaying the game much much more enjoyable as they allow you to fight your favourite bosses without having to replay the entire game again. Doesn't restock shops, which sucks, but it's still better than nothing.
This game also looks the best. DS1 and 3 are very ugly in comparison. DS2 is just stunning. It is also quite colourful, unlike 1 and 3 which have an unrealistic limited colour palette.

Pros:
- Locations are both wildly varied, stunning and oozing atmosphere
- Music, though sparse, is wonderful
- The pacing of the first 80% of the game is excellent and very satisfying
- Excellent variety of weapons
- NPCs well written and voiced
- Enemy variety broad and imaginative (though generally less intimidating than those of DS1)
- Excellent hub-world that doesn't feel like a cliche hub
- Difficulty ramps smoothly in first 80% of the game, making you feel ever-so-slightly behind the curve / under pressure at all times
- Full of pleasant surprises, such as some enemies fleeing when you're holding the blazing torch

Cons:
- Adaptability stat throws an unnecessary wrench into the game's mechanics
- Areas appear grand upon first encounter, but soon feel small once progress is made. Areas are more bite-sized than DS1
- Bosses are easier and less intimidating than in DS1
- Combat is clunkier than DS1, with large "I'll just wait here a moment while you cleave me open with your sword" windows of time for the enemy to punish you
- Locations, though beautiful, are less intimidating in their scale than in other DS games
- Parrying is less encouraged than in other SoulsBorne games, and when you do complete a parry your R1 attack is far far far less satisfying than in DS1
- Late game levelling becomes an absolute chore, with disappearing enemies, and difficult to find weapon upgrade materials. Making this section feel more like a job than a game.
- The pacing of the latter 20% of the game is a huge letdown. The final boss sits waiting for you in the mid-game area of Drangelic Castle, which robs the final confrontation of any sense-of-occasion. There's no hard-won battle to reach the boss, and therefore no gravitas. (The Throne should have been placed in a mountain-top castle, with a gruelling uphill gauntlet to fight through, filled with new enemies that train you to develop the skillset necessary to thwart the final boss, while building up a sense of intimidation via the perception of overwhelming odds, such as a lightning storm atop the castle that worsens as you approach, and eerie music full of diminished chords)
- DLC is resentfully cheap and difficult (I suspect the devs were upset about the game's initial reception and sought to prove themselves by way of difficulty-spiking the DLC with cheap lock-you-in-an-area gauntlets full of projectile-enemies that curse and mob you).

Recently played DS2 (SotFS), the only mainline FromSoftware game I hadn‚Äôt yet tried. After giving it a fair shot, I‚Äôm putting it aside. It lacks the appeal of Dark Souls or Elden Ring, and I don‚Äôt enjoy it enough as a standalone to keep playing.

Main issues:
- Disconnected, small levels feel like themed world checklists (pirate cove, castle, forest etc.). They're over as soon as they start and the lack of cohesion between them all makes them feel pointless.
- The hub-and-spoke world design isn't well implemented. Navigation and progression can be confusing.  In DS1 and DS3, even if you're lost, there's always somewhere to go and you don't often hit dead-ends.
- Controls feel off; enemy hitboxes are weird and the lock-on mechanism only seems to lock the camera, not your aim. This can make combat awkward and frustrating.
- SotFS is supposedly harder due to non-stop (!) trollish enemy placement. It slows the pace and gets tedious checking corners and behind to find enemies. Maybe this is an attempt to compensate for the levels being so short? Misses the mark if so.
- Health penalties on death didn‚Äôt bother me much, but might turn others off. I tend to play glass cannon characters and I found this encouraged me to focus on stats that improved mobility and dodging.
- Torches are ineffective and clunky‚Äîforcing one-handed combat, wasting time relighting, and often leaving me running in darkness unnecessarily. They're so unusual that I suspect their mechanics are relics from early development.

Overall, DS2‚Äôs PvE fails to hold my interest due to these issues. I‚Äôve heard PvP is good, so perhaps if you enjoy that, you might try it and enjoy the game if you don't expect much from the story or exploration.

For the rest, the game is full of ganks. Now ganks aren't inherently bad, but I'd argue most of the ganks in this game aren't well done. There are exceptions namely in the first area of the game especially in [spoiler]No man's Wharf, forest of fallen giants[/spoiler]. But after these early game area which are really nice, the game takes a turn and start just popping tons of enemies in corridor, ambush all the time. The same trick over and over again. All in all, I wouldn't call it the worse game in the world or anything.
